This is indeed confusing and hopefully next week we'll have a push (over a month in the making) that disallows this behavior. It's a bit out of scope of this bug to describe why this behavior is the way it is, but it's been the TF standard for a long time. But after this change, you'll have to write: MultiRNNCell([BasicLSTMCell(10) for _ in range(3)]) otherwise you will get an error when calling dynamic_rnn. With this version of the code, you end up creating 3 separate BasicLSTMCell instances, each of which expects to maintain its own parameters.

body:
This is indeed confusing and hopefully next week we'll have a push (over a
month in the making) that disallows this behavior.  It's a bit out of scope
of this bug to describe why this behavior is the way it is, but it's been
the TF standard for a long time.  But after this change, you'll have to
write:

MultiRNNCell([BasicLSTMCell(10) for _ in range(3)])

otherwise you will get an error when calling dynamic_rnn.

With this version of the code, you end up creating 3 separate BasicLSTMCell
instances, each of which expects to maintain its own parameters.
